job_title: P3 Software Engineer in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: I can’t think of any except work life balance and not even. Boeing expects you to work as a lead for 2 years before they promoted you to the level you are working. So in terms of work life balance you are expected to put in 50-60 hours while only working 40.
cons: Morale is at an all time low for software engineers. Most to all people on my team and other teams are actively training for interviews in order to leave. The compensation is about half for the area so most software engineers under P3 make under 113,000 in San Francisco and along Beach California. They actually gave effective pay cuts this year! In addition, Boeing recognize the lazy employees and overachievers the same. They prioritize years of experience and age over talent ,performance, and skills. If you are looking for a job and want minimum compensation come here. If you want to be paid fairly don’t come here and if you want to grow your technical skills don’t come here. Boeing does everything it can to dumb down its systems so they don’t have to hire software engineers. Truly a horrible place.

review_title: Boeing is no longer what it used to be
pros: Company overall offers good benefits (health, dental, child backup care, school tuition reimbursement, etc), reasonable work and life balance, semi comfortable work environment. In some states where racial diversity is broadly embraced such as WA, CA, OR, people from different cultures feel comfortable with each other and are open to share experiences and opinion. BCA and BGS encourage somewhat more open culture than BDS, reason is simple, BDS is defense sector, there is lots of red flags or rules on what can be shared or not.
cons:
Although public communication says company has hit rock bottom and is bouncing back, truth is this company is still on a downward spiral, it is struggling with rebranding. It is no longer a premium brand that people used to admire. Everyday customers complain about design defects, degradation in manufacturing and services quality, broken/ inadequate business processes, etc. Here is what a lot of people know…

Even though on annual earnings call Boeing tries to paint rosy picture that 737 MAX is back to service operating well, 777X is in entry into service phase and 787 back to delivery is in progress, the truth is there are so many technical issues and commercial claims against these models initiated by customers. Hearing from customers, feel bad for them buying planes and services from Boeing, because they don’t really know what they are getting into until 5 years into service. Products integrity and reliability, service performance are not performing per contract. Airplanes are marketed inconsistent to how they perform. If it is not for duopoly reason (Boeing and Airbus dominating the industry), BCA would be bankrupt already due to disasters on 737MAX and 787. Sadly these events will not be the last time Boeing faces it, something else will come up…

Also problem with Boeing internal bureaucracy is HUGE. Internal teams fight each other over who should own actions, they all push around saying that budget or resources constraint is prevalent. First line and senior management are hesitant to step up to take a lead unless executives get involved and give a marching order. This is a top down culture. Even though internal communication says we encourage people speaking up and want them be creative, share ideas, but truth is whoever owns the money speak.

pros:
- Defined processes and existing programs are decent aspects to learn from as an entry level engineer.
- Benefits are good
- Work your 40 hours and log off
cons:
- Salaries are low for Seattle cost of living
- There are so many internal problems right now across all programs that is almost embarrassing to work here.
- Management refuses to invest in its engineering teams. Many engineering tools are going on 30-40 years old.
- Simple engineering decisions have to go through multiple rounds of review boards, when a decision could simply be made by a responsible engineer.
- Most of the best older engineers left the company during COVID voluntary layoffs, and some of the most promising younger engineers were involuntarily laid off during COVID layoffs in 2020. Now they are hiring warm bodies off the street or fresh out of college.
- Company is forgetting or has already forgot how to build new airplanes. 
- Retention is at an all-time low, turnover all-time high.
- Salary progression is pretty much based on years of service, not based on accomplishments. This incentivizes early/mid-career go-getter engineers to work elsewhere after 2-5 years to earn what they are worth and to do real engineering.
- Working relationship with FAA does not exist, putting all commercial airplane development programs at risk

I can't wait to leave. My passion for commercial aviation has been eliminated the past few years. I fear the company has not yet reached its bottom.

review_title: Not What It Used to Be
pros: I came to Boeing quite some time ago and was drawn by The Boeing Company's reputation for engineering excellence. I admired the company and was proud to say that I worked for the preeminent aircraft manufacturer in the world. That stayed with me and continued to underpin my attitude toward the company. However,....see the 'Cons'
cons:
However, in the wake of the 737 Max accidents, I became more aware of the attenuated focus on engineering and a accentuated focus on stock price.
In the shakeup that followed the accidents an even more disturbing corporate philosophy emerged--the woke "philosophy" characterized by an over-emphasis on diversity for diversity's sake, e.g. assigning and hiring with an emphasis on 'diversity' over knowledge, skills and abilities, an activist leadership team speaking out about sociopolitical topics that have nothing to do with building and/or operating aerospace products and the rest of the nauseating, activist follow-the-leader, mindless behavior that characterizes the "movement". In general, this company seems to have lost a focus on what William E Boeing would have considered important and what made this company survive for 105 years. Without a course change, The Boeing Company will not see more than a score or so of additional birthdays.

review_title: Save your career,  just say NO
job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Renton, WA
pros: Some benefits, really cool products built.
cons: Want a career where you choose your jobs? Not here. There are near constant reorganizations. Want to be promoted? Sorry, also not the place for you unless you are right out of college. Salary increase? Oops, that only comes with promotions. Same manager who wants to help you achieve your career development? Sorry, you'll go through an average of one new manager every 6-8 months. In the past 10 years, either health insurance premiums have either gone up, or the benefits covered were reduced. Save yourself the trouble. The only thing "cutting edge" about Boeing is the ingrained level of taking advantage of employees while simultaneously making you grateful you survived**this** round of layoffs. "One Boeing" doesn't exist...Your pay and benefits vary by which of the 80+ unions, or locations, or business units you support. Even though the merit rating scale includes a "far exceeds" it is so mythical that no one I have met (including those working two levels above what they are hired as) has achieved one.

review_title: Not a good time to join the company. Bait & switch to get new hires
job_title: Electrical Design Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: 401k and healthcare are good but the competition is increasingly offering similar and/or better benefits. They will tout their benefits as if you'll never get a better offer on the planet. Not true, like most of what they told me.
cons:
Everything I was told about the position I interviewed for ended up not being true. I tried to make the unfortunate situation work by communicating to my manager what I expected when I joined. Again didn't listen at all. I was consistently set up to fail by being placed in environments that are direct opposite of what I sought out during interview. 

I worked with Incredibly lazy coworkers interested in milking the company for all its worth while doing the most minimal amount of work. Lots of talk about engineering but barely any true engineering work. 4 hours of complaining with 4 hours of talking about engineering. If you are lazy and uninterested in growing your career, this is the place for you.

This is the most negative workforce I have ever encountered. I tried networking and was told by every single peer to look for outside opportunities if I'm ambitious and passionate about engineering, which I am. I took their advice and received a 30% pay boost.

I recommend adhering to the overwhelming negative feedback reported on Glassdoor, LinkedIn, Reddit, etc. I thought it was a case of the loudest voices but unfortunately it was spot on.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Highly accomplished, goal-oriented, and result-focused professional with over 15+ years of project and program management, project engineering, proposal management, strategic marketing, new business development, and graphics/web design experience. A proactive and collaborative individual with keen business acumen specializing in growing, increasing, advancing, and sustaining business opportunities. Demonstrated exceptional time management and organizational skills with the ability to handle several complex projects simultaneously by implementing best practices and procedures to ensure delivery are on schedule and within budget. Expert in utilizing Program Management Best Practices (PMBP) with proven success in generating multi-million dollar competitive proposals to include Commercial Aircraft (A/C) Platforms, Multi-Military Platforms, Engineering, Software Blocks, Material, Repair, and Maintenance. Possess superior analytical and problem-solving skills adept at understanding requirements, translating them into practical, sustainable solutions and seizing control of critical problem areas. Proven ability to work across many functions and thrive in a fast-paced environment with unmatched strengths in developmental management, end-to-end delivery, tactical leadership, and follow-through on critical company projects and goals.
cons: 15+ years of project and program management, project engineering, proposal management, strategic marketing, new business development, and graphics/web design experience.

review_title: Boeing India has no product/technology ownership
pros:
- Good work/life balance
- Not much challenging work to do, so if you want to have a leisure time at home then it is a good company for you.
cons:
- No ownership of technology & product, hence not much control over work that you do. 
- Core requirements come from US team, decisions are taken from US team, no participation in any decision discussion whatsoever
- Projects are mainly taken over from service based companies like TCS, Infosys, which were delegated to these companies by Boeing earlier.
- India team is treated as service/maintenance team with no control over any development activities
- Roles & responsibilities are not defined, it's like survival of the fittest environment, projects are not challenging but the work environment is.
- As it is not an IT company, no defined processes for Quality, Project or Product Management.
- As it is not an IT company, and as India team is considered as maintenance provider, pay is around 70% below market average.

job_title: Aircraft Technician in Ridley Park, PA
pros:
Benefits and the union makes it very hard to get fired so it retains alot of turds.
There are some great techs who really care, but are bogged down with the union mentality of taking your time and no need to care so much. If you do show you care enough it can be a great learning experience.
cons:
There are two pay scales one for senior guys who've topped at 45$ and hr, but newer employees like myself who were hired 2020 or after get put on table two, so you start at about 26.25 and top out at about 30. I almost feel like a contractor with this pay scale, it's ridiculous for the amount of work that we do. Almost all of the talented guys I talk to have been looking for new higher paying jobs, and I'm doing the same.
The CCRAM program is garbage, the managers steal parts from aircraft and don't properly document it. When techs go to reinstall parts on other aircraft which parts were taken from, it becomes a nightmare to complete jobs. Boeing is a great company, but retaining people because of seniority and hiring managers who will beg borrow or steal to keep their numbers up will keep driving this company into the ground.
Good luck Boeing! Thanks for the memories.

review_title: Acceptable but don't expect competitive compensation
pros:
Basic compensation needs met to retain average or below average talent.
Big company with lots of internal job opportunities.
cons:
Company will not compete on salary to keep talented employees. They have an outdated and underrated salary lookup table and refuse to recognize increases in market compensation and continue to lose talent as a result. 

Mid-senior level new hires will be disappointed by the entry level vacation days offered (2 weeks). The company is completely inflexible negotiating this because it is defined in the union contract.

Extremely management heavy workforce. An engineer has 8 layers of management above them to reach the CEO. During layoffs, management is untouchable. After all the engineers are laid off, lower quality managers are demoted to the highest engineering levels. 

Union dues must be paid or else be terminated by breach of contract. All new employees fall under a lower class tier of benefits than the previous hire date vintages which receive pension, retiree medical benefits and higher 401k matching amounts. New employees are required to pay the same union dues even though they receive lower tier benefits, thereby are forced to fund and support the bifurcated class system which holds them back.

job_title: Procurement Agent I in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
-The benefits look like a great offer at first. 
-Work like balance is good up until a certain point.
-Some management deserves praise.
cons:
Where do I begin?

-Turnover rate is insane in the Procurement Department due to lack of accountability among project management, engineering, and procurement planners. Management actively refers to Procurement as the “Meat Grinder” due to burnout, impacts on employee health, and turnover rate yet does nothing to improve the situation.
-The benefits package is used to make you feel better about being underpaid compared to competitors. Sadly the only benefits that actually provide any value is the health care. You won’t find yourself using 90% of the other benefits used by management to out way your lack of salary.
-Raises have been scarce and mediocre at best
-The entire work environment is on edge after 3 rounds of voluntary and involuntary layoffs over the past few years. 
-Favoritism and elitism is rampant. Majority of the staff has been told promotions were on hold only to see favorited employees be made offers.
-70% of management had no concept of work/life balance, maintaining a healthy work environment, and lacked the basic principles of the department that they have been assigned to.
-Don’t expect any consistency as management can’t decide what they want job duties, policies, and procedures to look like for more than a few months at a time.

review_title: Hasn't kept up with the times
pros:
Large company virtually guarantees a wide variety of work. There is almost certainly a job that you will enjoy at Boeing if you are willing to dig for it.

While the pay is average the benefits are actually pretty good, particularly the 401k match.
cons:
Many systems (both hardware and software) and processes have not been updated since well before the turn of the century, haven't been maintained, and are barely holding together (duct tape and chewing gum is only a slight exaggeration). As a result you are going to spend way more time then you need setting up anything hardware related. It was not unusually to spend hours setting up for 10-15 minutes of testing, and that was if you could get the hardware working at all.

Any requests to management to fix these issues will fall on deaf ears. Either the program does not have the time or budget for it or its clearly not an issue and you just need to work more hours to compensate.

The majority of programs seem to always be millions overbudget and years behind schedule. In addition there is rarely consensus from the powers that be over the priority of work. As you might imagine this does not exactly create a calm workplace that is conducive to doing your best work.

The companies age can also lead to a bit of an old boys club in certain areas, where if you haven't been there for at least a decade don't bother your opinion will not be taken into account.

Pay is a bit on the low end. A first year engineer at Google will make about the same as an end of career senior engineer at Boeing.

job_title: Chief of Staff in Everett, WA
pros: Amazing environment to learn and grow if you have the motivation to. Boeing provides applicable education, training, certification, and apprenticeship opportunities at every level. If you are a go-getter, there are many choices in career path that you can take advantage of, without ever leaving the company!
cons: The yearly review process has evolved to be very rigorous and can be quite intimidating and varied across the organizations, departments, and the management staff responsible for performing the reviews. There is INTENSE competition within the distinctive job skill groups, and you MUST rise in your performance, or you will not be kept on. It has evolved out of the notorious "Lazy B" where you could sleep on the job and have your brother, neighbor, or father-in-law cover for you. It's not the same business environment, and it's not the same old Boeing. They MUST be competitive and that means only value added employees are maintained.

review_title: Boeing appreciates, values and rewards hard work with top-notch benefits
pros:
Loyal (Boeing truly cares about giving us the best compensation package possible, 401K benefits with a 6% match if you give 8% (it’s 75% up to 8% max), unlimited learning opportunities both for degree-seekers and skill-oriented learners wishing to better their professional or technical skill sets), competitive starting salary with annual raises set by the SPEEA union (guaranteed), Union represented (can’t be laid off in 1 days time, for example — also those who’re let go get first call backs, if lay offs do unfortunately come — during covid, 1/3 of the factory I worked at was let go o retired early if you were a seasoned employee who took advantage of the pay-out, now I work with familiar faces a year later, so they truly to prioritize getting you back when market conditions hurt the company)
Fun workplace (something new to do and a new problem to solve every day; as a process engineer, I get to perform root cause analysis, delve into chemical processing applications like anodizing and etching processes, and learning useful manufacturing work processes like shot peening, forming, CNC milling, electrostatic spray painting and kitting fabricated parts for delivery to final assembly factories)
Valued in both my conversations with older engineers who have tremendous amounts of useful experience that I don’t have (not ostracized)
Learning opportunities & future education opportunities (work & get your next degree paid for, and pick any degree you want basically, but you must be employed for at least a year)
Camaraderie all over the factory in each work area (fabrication plants)
cons:
Outsourcing
Gargantuan 
Disheveled
Unpredictability of the aerospace industry (lay offs)
Detached from HQ (they just want to know how much we’re contributing, though they do trust us and they don’t hover)

pros: Quality of life is great with no overtime.  Working with great professional people at the salaried level
cons: Lots of red tape.  Everything requires research to get anything done.

pros: Pay hours and was good environment
cons: No benefits as most employees are contractors

review_title: Boeing is an eclectic, amazing and inclusive place to work!
pros: I have worked at Boeing in multiple locations as well as virtually. I have worked on cross functional teams and had a myriad of experiences in my function. The opportunities for growth and the variety of experiences available in one company are unprecedented. The diversity of both the programs/products and the people makes the work inviting, inclusive, educational and inspiring. I never hesitate to recommend Boeing to friends, family and the public (on social platforms). Boeing has provided me with fulfillment and provided my family with opportunities previous generations of my family only dreamed of.
cons: Depending on the position sought, I feel Boeing's size, global presence, reliance on technology and diversity of products and people might be a challenge for some who desire to be in a small company with with only a single location or monolithic product line. That said, it is worthy to note that some sites and subsidiaries around Boeing and the positions available there do provide a "small company" feel at times. Regardless, the good news is, Boeing's inclusive and equity-minded values pervade the enterprise!

job_title: Aviation Maintenance Technician in Everett, WA
pros: If you are motivated to do a decent job and not just do the minimum there are or has been plenty of opportunities to excel. It has been a great company to work for and it has allowed me to raise a family comfortably and in my case because of my time in service now have an okay retirement check each month. Remember those of you who are still with the Boeing Company you are part of the Boeing Company and if you want to see it improve you have to be willing to work to turn it back around.
cons:
The pay could be better for those working their way up and for it to not take so long to reach full scale. You cannot raise a family on what they are willing to pay the young/newer folks which is a shame. And the benefits have declined over the years which is one of the things that was a plus with employment at the Boeing Company. If you want to retain good folks you have to be willing to compensate them for the work performed and encourage them to go above and beyond just doing the minimum. 
As far as the management goes, they have removed most of the incentives for going into management and the changes have been evident in the attitudes of some of the managers. I have witnessed many managers that let the troops know that they are not happy with the lack of being properly compensated for overtime and lack of upper management support.

review_title: Decent if you know what to expect
pros: The company is very comfy to work at, and the pay and bennies are pretty decent. The workload is pretty manageable, and I didn't often feel pressured to work more than 40 hrs a week. Engineers still get overtime, which is amazing. There are a lot of people that work there that are passionate about aerospace with amazing stories. Two weeks off at Christmas is nice, even if I feel the less senior people at the company could use more vacation time. Just don't expect much of a pay raise unless you get extremely lucky and work on an important project.
cons: When I started, I really enjoyed it. Granted, I was younger and this was my first job at a large company. It quickly becomes obvious that most engineers are just interchangeable "work units" to management, intended to crank out product. Despite what they tell you, moving from position to position is not wise to do for career advancement because of their horrible skill code system. If you switch skill codes, you essentially reset any possibility of a promotion for at least 3-4 years. They fire and re-hire people on a regular cycle to keep costs down. If you are ok with the possibility boomeranging back and forth from employment to unemployment every 3 years or so, go for it. When they finally let me go during covid after 9 consecutive years of service and surviving several mass layoffs, I decided I didn't want to do that anymore and have since switched careers.

review_title: Great place to start your career and spend a few years
job_title: Structures and Payload Design Engineer in Everett, WA
pros:
Pay was good considering I joined them fresh out of college.

Benefits were great, 401k matching was generous (union), healthcare was low cost with generous company HSA contribution every year. 

Vacation wise, they could be better but considering you can accumulate vacation and sick leave (union), it was not bad.

Back when the company was doing good, bonuses were also a plus (EIP) although not as competitive as other tech companies in the Puget Sound area.

Had a pretty good experience with my immediate supervisors and colleagues.
cons:
Merit increases/pay raises were negotiated by the union. Before 2017, management had a 5% raise pool with a minimum of 1.5-2%  guaranteed raise every year. Assuming you were a high performer, you could expect anywhere from 4-7% raises every year. 

After the 2016 contract negotiation everything changed, the raise pool averaged 2-3% with 0% guaranteed raises. They incorporated a lump sum amount which averaged 2-3%. So under this scheme my 4-7% raise turned into a 2-3% raise and 2-3% lump sum (cash bonus). Not bad but not great considering Puget Sound is a high cost of living area with tech companies offering generous compensation packages

-Management and company cultured heavily entrenched in their ways and unwilling to change, partially due to government-related bureaucracy, but also just having a larger amount of older employees

If you want to stay on the production floor, it's easy enough to move around using the internal transfer tool, but salary is a different story.

-Management overly focused on numbers and metrics and thus push processes even if they're inefficient and cause more issues and work for the employees, "LEAN" manufacturing widely discussed but in reality is complete lip service in regards to real life situations on the floor.

review_title: Going More in the Wrong Direction
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Benefits are really good minus the salary but they more than make up in benefits.
They pay for schooling which honestly is the best in the industry.
Very little performance is required. There are large swaths of the company where zero work is required and managers are not capable letting go of people. If you are even half talented you are going to rise above the rest of the company. I would still recommend working there just educate yourself so they don't teach you how to do things incorrectly. That way you will still be marketable.
cons: The people in charge have very little understanding of software. They see software tools as a cost rather than something needed to do your job more efficiently. They don't really have a concept of efficiency as a metric. First time quality is lacking. The tools are at least 10 years behind throughout the company. Simple source control principles are not known by the majority contributors. The facilities are in disrepair. The restrooms are unclean and unmaintained to the point where I was embarrassed to bring in customers because it was unprofessional. They are basically taking any money to spend on folks and giving it to the management who are generally failing. They rotate them through after they lose programs instead of marching people out of the door for failure. This is demotivating for those who work hard and want to excel.

review_title: Big Machine Stuck with Old Way of Thinking
job_title: Lead Manufacturing Engineer in Huntsville, AL
pros: As long as you are a performer, you have job security. Pretty much only way to be fired is to be laid off (which is a con for those that do perform and see non-performers making more money). Has great benefits package. Yearly bonus based on combination of personal and corporate divisions performance.
cons: Managers operate off of loyalty rather than objectiveness. Can't get a raise or promotion unless you leave the program. HR is a joke and are deterred from reporting despite their open/anonymous policy. If you are the only female in an entire department and can only 'anonymously' report from your company computer, is it really anonymous? Stories of people in the past say HR often doesn't provide support and end up only hurting your career. If they do support, then you still obtain a reputation among managers. Have heard hiring managers discuss candidates for a high ranking positions and actually said they would rather hire the women not because of her qualifications but because she seems 'easier to control'.

review_title: Met some great people but disappointed overall
pros: Health benefits are pretty good and their 401k match is the best I've ever seen. Adding Boeing to your resume is a nice to have especially if you're up and coming. You'll meet some of the nicest and collaborative people if you're lucky.
cons: Lots of tenured people are basically waiting to get their turn to get promoted to a higher level. Managers aren't necessarily looking to help advance your career as they should unless you're part of their clique. Morale has been even worse in 2021 compared to 2020 when all the layoffs were happening. Technology is also behind the times. It is super political especially in management. Managers call themselves leaders bc they think it's what they are by title but unfortunately, it is just a facade that most people can see right through. They're talking the talk but not walking the walk. Top talent aren't valued and as a result, many leave.

review_title: Not as advertised. BCFP is neither rigorous nor "accelerating"
job_title: Business Career Foundation Program in Seattle, WA
pros: Good benefits (health insurance, 401k)
cons:
1. Management does not actually care about early career employees. You can spend two years in the BCFP and then place out of the program into another entry level job
2. Salary is far below industry standards
3. Some pockets of extremely toxic work culture (i.e. backstabbing, coworkers who complain about those who take PTO because they have to backfill their work, micromanagement, distrust among teams, I could go on and on...)
4. The BCFP is a glorified early career program that promises participants an accelerated career track, but you will likely spend a year and a half doing administrative work (or doing no real work at all under the guise of "shadowing")
5. Program managers are either clueless or willfully ignorant of the program's shortcomings

pros: Benefits are awesome if you are in the union. I got my degree and left. Plenty of opportunity for growth. The internal job transferring is structured in a way that rewards people who put in the work to learn additional skills. They take safety serious most of the time. Christmas break every year.
cons:
Terrible and inconsistent management. I had more than fifteen different managers during my six years with the company. Maybe one or two that I thought were competent. Too often the poor management decisions would cause me to have to work mandatory overtime. Senior management was constantly pushing "corporate values" that felt like a thinly veiled attempt at being "woke". It was at least a little cringe most of the time.

Even worse, the average airplane mechanic was mostly awful to be around. Disrespectful and disgusting, there were a lot of the typical anti-vax and self proclaimed "redneck" folk. Many of these types exhibited racist behaviors and speech throughout the day. If you can look past all of that, it's a pretty good job. Despite the extremely generous benefits, I hated it here. I would recommend it only if you get an office job.

job_title: P3 Software Engineer in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: I can’t think of any except work life balance and not even. Boeing expects you to work as a lead for 2 years before they promoted you to the level you are working. So in terms of work life balance you are expected to put in 50-60 hours while only working 40.
cons: Morale is at an all time low for software engineers. Most to all people on my team and other teams are actively training for interviews in order to leave. The compensation is about half for the area so most software engineers under P3 make under 113,000 in San Francisco and along Beach California. They actually gave effective pay cuts this year! In addition, Boeing recognize the lazy employees and overachievers the same. They prioritize years of experience and age over talent ,performance, and skills. If you are looking for a job and want minimum compensation come here. If you want to be paid fairly don’t come here and if you want to grow your technical skills don’t come here. Boeing does everything it can to dumb down its systems so they don’t have to hire software engineers. Truly a horrible place.

review_title: Boeing is no longer what it used to be
pros: Company overall offers good benefits (health, dental, child backup care, school tuition reimbursement, etc), reasonable work and life balance, semi comfortable work environment. In some states where racial diversity is broadly embraced such as WA, CA, OR, people from different cultures feel comfortable with each other and are open to share experiences and opinion. BCA and BGS encourage somewhat more open culture than BDS, reason is simple, BDS is defense sector, there is lots of red flags or rules on what can be shared or not.
cons:
Although public communication says company has hit rock bottom and is bouncing back, truth is this company is still on a downward spiral, it is struggling with rebranding. It is no longer a premium brand that people used to admire. Everyday customers complain about design defects, degradation in manufacturing and services quality, broken/ inadequate business processes, etc. Here is what a lot of people know…

Even though on annual earnings call Boeing tries to paint rosy picture that 737 MAX is back to service operating well, 777X is in entry into service phase and 787 back to delivery is in progress, the truth is there are so many technical issues and commercial claims against these models initiated by customers. Hearing from customers, feel bad for them buying planes and services from Boeing, because they don’t really know what they are getting into until 5 years into service. Products integrity and reliability, service performance are not performing per contract. Airplanes are marketed inconsistent to how they perform. If it is not for duopoly reason (Boeing and Airbus dominating the industry), BCA would be bankrupt already due to disasters on 737MAX and 787. Sadly these events will not be the last time Boeing faces it, something else will come up…

Also problem with Boeing internal bureaucracy is HUGE. Internal teams fight each other over who should own actions, they all push around saying that budget or resources constraint is prevalent. First line and senior management are hesitant to step up to take a lead unless executives get involved and give a marching order. This is a top down culture. Even though internal communication says we encourage people speaking up and want them be creative, share ideas, but truth is whoever owns the money speak.

pros:
- Defined processes and existing programs are decent aspects to learn from as an entry level engineer.
- Benefits are good
- Work your 40 hours and log off
cons:
- Salaries are low for Seattle cost of living
- There are so many internal problems right now across all programs that is almost embarrassing to work here.
- Management refuses to invest in its engineering teams. Many engineering tools are going on 30-40 years old.
- Simple engineering decisions have to go through multiple rounds of review boards, when a decision could simply be made by a responsible engineer.
- Most of the best older engineers left the company during COVID voluntary layoffs, and some of the most promising younger engineers were involuntarily laid off during COVID layoffs in 2020. Now they are hiring warm bodies off the street or fresh out of college.
- Company is forgetting or has already forgot how to build new airplanes. 
- Retention is at an all-time low, turnover all-time high.
- Salary progression is pretty much based on years of service, not based on accomplishments. This incentivizes early/mid-career go-getter engineers to work elsewhere after 2-5 years to earn what they are worth and to do real engineering.
- Working relationship with FAA does not exist, putting all commercial airplane development programs at risk

I can't wait to leave. My passion for commercial aviation has been eliminated the past few years. I fear the company has not yet reached its bottom.

review_title: Not What It Used to Be
pros: I came to Boeing quite some time ago and was drawn by The Boeing Company's reputation for engineering excellence. I admired the company and was proud to say that I worked for the preeminent aircraft manufacturer in the world. That stayed with me and continued to underpin my attitude toward the company. However,....see the 'Cons'
cons:
However, in the wake of the 737 Max accidents, I became more aware of the attenuated focus on engineering and a accentuated focus on stock price.
In the shakeup that followed the accidents an even more disturbing corporate philosophy emerged--the woke "philosophy" characterized by an over-emphasis on diversity for diversity's sake, e.g. assigning and hiring with an emphasis on 'diversity' over knowledge, skills and abilities, an activist leadership team speaking out about sociopolitical topics that have nothing to do with building and/or operating aerospace products and the rest of the nauseating, activist follow-the-leader, mindless behavior that characterizes the "movement". In general, this company seems to have lost a focus on what William E Boeing would have considered important and what made this company survive for 105 years. Without a course change, The Boeing Company will not see more than a score or so of additional birthdays.

review_title: Save your career,  just say NO
pros: Some benefits, really cool products built.
cons: Want a career where you choose your jobs? Not here. There are near constant reorganizations. Want to be promoted? Sorry, also not the place for you unless you are right out of college. Salary increase? Oops, that only comes with promotions. Same manager who wants to help you achieve your career development? Sorry, you'll go through an average of one new manager every 6-8 months. In the past 10 years, either health insurance premiums have either gone up, or the benefits covered were reduced. Save yourself the trouble. The only thing "cutting edge" about Boeing is the ingrained level of taking advantage of employees while simultaneously making you grateful you survived**this** round of layoffs. "One Boeing" doesn't exist...Your pay and benefits vary by which of the 80+ unions, or locations, or business units you support. Even though the merit rating scale includes a "far exceeds" it is so mythical that no one I have met (including those working two levels above what they are hired as) has achieved one.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Highly accomplished, goal-oriented, and result-focused professional with over 15+ years of project and program management, project engineering, proposal management, strategic marketing, new business development, and graphics/web design experience. A proactive and collaborative individual with keen business acumen specializing in growing, increasing, advancing, and sustaining business opportunities. Demonstrated exceptional time management and organizational skills with the ability to handle several complex projects simultaneously by implementing best practices and procedures to ensure delivery are on schedule and within budget. Expert in utilizing Program Management Best Practices (PMBP) with proven success in generating multi-million dollar competitive proposals to include Commercial Aircraft (A/C) Platforms, Multi-Military Platforms, Engineering, Software Blocks, Material, Repair, and Maintenance. Possess superior analytical and problem-solving skills adept at understanding requirements, translating them into practical, sustainable solutions and seizing control of critical problem areas. Proven ability to work across many functions and thrive in a fast-paced environment with unmatched strengths in developmental management, end-to-end delivery, tactical leadership, and follow-through on critical company projects and goals.
cons: 15+ years of project and program management, project engineering, proposal management, strategic marketing, new business development, and graphics/web design experience.

review_title: Not a good time to join the company. Bait & switch to get new hires
job_title: Electrical Design Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: 401k and healthcare are good but the competition is increasingly offering similar and/or better benefits. They will tout their benefits as if you'll never get a better offer on the planet. Not true, like most of what they told me.
cons:
Everything I was told about the position I interviewed for ended up not being true. I tried to make the unfortunate situation work by communicating to my manager what I expected when I joined. Again didn't listen at all. I was consistently set up to fail by being placed in environments that are direct opposite of what I sought out during interview. 

I worked with Incredibly lazy coworkers interested in milking the company for all its worth while doing the most minimal amount of work. Lots of talk about engineering but barely any true engineering work. 4 hours of complaining with 4 hours of talking about engineering. If you are lazy and uninterested in growing your career, this is the place for you.

This is the most negative workforce I have ever encountered. I tried networking and was told by every single peer to look for outside opportunities if I'm ambitious and passionate about engineering, which I am. I took their advice and received a 30% pay boost.

I recommend adhering to the overwhelming negative feedback reported on Glassdoor, LinkedIn, Reddit, etc. I thought it was a case of the loudest voices but unfortunately it was spot on.

review_title: Boeing India has no product/technology ownership
pros:
- Good work/life balance
- Not much challenging work to do, so if you want to have a leisure time at home then it is a good company for you.
cons:
- No ownership of technology & product, hence not much control over work that you do. 
- Core requirements come from US team, decisions are taken from US team, no participation in any decision discussion whatsoever
- Projects are mainly taken over from service based companies like TCS, Infosys, which were delegated to these companies by Boeing earlier.
- India team is treated as service/maintenance team with no control over any development activities
- Roles & responsibilities are not defined, it's like survival of the fittest environment, projects are not challenging but the work environment is.
- As it is not an IT company, no defined processes for Quality, Project or Product Management.
- As it is not an IT company, and as India team is considered as maintenance provider, pay is around 70% below market average.

pros: Sometimes they have to go through deep layoffs. So very hard on everyone.

review_title: Management only cares about numbers not your success
job_title: Aircraft Technician in Ridley Park, PA
pros:
Benefits and the union makes it very hard to get fired so it retains alot of turds.
There are some great techs who really care, but are bogged down with the union mentality of taking your time and no need to care so much. If you do show you care enough it can be a great learning experience.
cons:
There are two pay scales one for senior guys who've topped at 45$ and hr, but newer employees like myself who were hired 2020 or after get put on table two, so you start at about 26.25 and top out at about 30. I almost feel like a contractor with this pay scale, it's ridiculous for the amount of work that we do. Almost all of the talented guys I talk to have been looking for new higher paying jobs, and I'm doing the same.
The CCRAM program is garbage, the managers steal parts from aircraft and don't properly document it. When techs go to reinstall parts on other aircraft which parts were taken from, it becomes a nightmare to complete jobs. Boeing is a great company, but retaining people because of seniority and hiring managers who will beg borrow or steal to keep their numbers up will keep driving this company into the ground.
Good luck Boeing! Thanks for the memories.

review_title: Acceptable but don't expect competitive compensation
pros:
Basic compensation needs met to retain average or below average talent.
Big company with lots of internal job opportunities.
cons:
Company will not compete on salary to keep talented employees. They have an outdated and underrated salary lookup table and refuse to recognize increases in market compensation and continue to lose talent as a result. 

Mid-senior level new hires will be disappointed by the entry level vacation days offered (2 weeks). The company is completely inflexible negotiating this because it is defined in the union contract.

Extremely management heavy workforce. An engineer has 8 layers of management above them to reach the CEO. During layoffs, management is untouchable. After all the engineers are laid off, lower quality managers are demoted to the highest engineering levels. 

Union dues must be paid or else be terminated by breach of contract. All new employees fall under a lower class tier of benefits than the previous hire date vintages which receive pension, retiree medical benefits and higher 401k matching amounts. New employees are required to pay the same union dues even though they receive lower tier benefits, thereby are forced to fund and support the bifurcated class system which holds them back.

job_title: Procurement Agent I in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
-The benefits look like a great offer at first. 
-Work like balance is good up until a certain point.
-Some management deserves praise.
cons:
Where do I begin?

-Turnover rate is insane in the Procurement Department due to lack of accountability among project management, engineering, and procurement planners. Management actively refers to Procurement as the “Meat Grinder” due to burnout, impacts on employee health, and turnover rate yet does nothing to improve the situation.
-The benefits package is used to make you feel better about being underpaid compared to competitors. Sadly the only benefits that actually provide any value is the health care. You won’t find yourself using 90% of the other benefits used by management to out way your lack of salary.
-Raises have been scarce and mediocre at best
-The entire work environment is on edge after 3 rounds of voluntary and involuntary layoffs over the past few years. 
-Favoritism and elitism is rampant. Majority of the staff has been told promotions were on hold only to see favorited employees be made offers.
-70% of management had no concept of work/life balance, maintaining a healthy work environment, and lacked the basic principles of the department that they have been assigned to.
-Don’t expect any consistency as management can’t decide what they want job duties, policies, and procedures to look like for more than a few months at a time.

review_title: Hasn't kept up with the times
pros:
Large company virtually guarantees a wide variety of work. There is almost certainly a job that you will enjoy at Boeing if you are willing to dig for it.

While the pay is average the benefits are actually pretty good, particularly the 401k match.
cons:
Many systems (both hardware and software) and processes have not been updated since well before the turn of the century, haven't been maintained, and are barely holding together (duct tape and chewing gum is only a slight exaggeration). As a result you are going to spend way more time then you need setting up anything hardware related. It was not unusually to spend hours setting up for 10-15 minutes of testing, and that was if you could get the hardware working at all.

Any requests to management to fix these issues will fall on deaf ears. Either the program does not have the time or budget for it or its clearly not an issue and you just need to work more hours to compensate.

The majority of programs seem to always be millions overbudget and years behind schedule. In addition there is rarely consensus from the powers that be over the priority of work. As you might imagine this does not exactly create a calm workplace that is conducive to doing your best work.

The companies age can also lead to a bit of an old boys club in certain areas, where if you haven't been there for at least a decade don't bother your opinion will not be taken into account.

Pay is a bit on the low end. A first year engineer at Google will make about the same as an end of career senior engineer at Boeing.

job_title: Chief of Staff in Everett, WA
pros: Amazing environment to learn and grow if you have the motivation to. Boeing provides applicable education, training, certification, and apprenticeship opportunities at every level. If you are a go-getter, there are many choices in career path that you can take advantage of, without ever leaving the company!
cons: The yearly review process has evolved to be very rigorous and can be quite intimidating and varied across the organizations, departments, and the management staff responsible for performing the reviews. There is INTENSE competition within the distinctive job skill groups, and you MUST rise in your performance, or you will not be kept on. It has evolved out of the notorious "Lazy B" where you could sleep on the job and have your brother, neighbor, or father-in-law cover for you. It's not the same business environment, and it's not the same old Boeing. They MUST be competitive and that means only value added employees are maintained.

review_title: Boeing appreciates, values and rewards hard work with top-notch benefits
pros:
Loyal (Boeing truly cares about giving us the best compensation package possible, 401K benefits with a 6% match if you give 8% (it’s 75% up to 8% max), unlimited learning opportunities both for degree-seekers and skill-oriented learners wishing to better their professional or technical skill sets), competitive starting salary with annual raises set by the SPEEA union (guaranteed), Union represented (can’t be laid off in 1 days time, for example — also those who’re let go get first call backs, if lay offs do unfortunately come — during covid, 1/3 of the factory I worked at was let go o retired early if you were a seasoned employee who took advantage of the pay-out, now I work with familiar faces a year later, so they truly to prioritize getting you back when market conditions hurt the company)
Fun workplace (something new to do and a new problem to solve every day; as a process engineer, I get to perform root cause analysis, delve into chemical processing applications like anodizing and etching processes, and learning useful manufacturing work processes like shot peening, forming, CNC milling, electrostatic spray painting and kitting fabricated parts for delivery to final assembly factories)
Valued in both my conversations with older engineers who have tremendous amounts of useful experience that I don’t have (not ostracized)
Learning opportunities & future education opportunities (work & get your next degree paid for, and pick any degree you want basically, but you must be employed for at least a year)
Camaraderie all over the factory in each work area (fabrication plants)
cons:
Outsourcing
Gargantuan 
Disheveled
Unpredictability of the aerospace industry (lay offs)
Detached from HQ (they just want to know how much we’re contributing, though they do trust us and they don’t hover)

review_title: Boeing is an eclectic, amazing and inclusive place to work!
pros: I have worked at Boeing in multiple locations as well as virtually. I have worked on cross functional teams and had a myriad of experiences in my function. The opportunities for growth and the variety of experiences available in one company are unprecedented. The diversity of both the programs/products and the people makes the work inviting, inclusive, educational and inspiring. I never hesitate to recommend Boeing to friends, family and the public (on social platforms). Boeing has provided me with fulfillment and provided my family with opportunities previous generations of my family only dreamed of.
cons: Depending on the position sought, I feel Boeing's size, global presence, reliance on technology and diversity of products and people might be a challenge for some who desire to be in a small company with with only a single location or monolithic product line. That said, it is worthy to note that some sites and subsidiaries around Boeing and the positions available there do provide a "small company" feel at times. Regardless, the good news is, Boeing's inclusive and equity-minded values pervade the enterprise!

job_title: Aviation Maintenance Technician in Everett, WA
pros: If you are motivated to do a decent job and not just do the minimum there are or has been plenty of opportunities to excel. It has been a great company to work for and it has allowed me to raise a family comfortably and in my case because of my time in service now have an okay retirement check each month. Remember those of you who are still with the Boeing Company you are part of the Boeing Company and if you want to see it improve you have to be willing to work to turn it back around.
cons:
The pay could be better for those working their way up and for it to not take so long to reach full scale. You cannot raise a family on what they are willing to pay the young/newer folks which is a shame. And the benefits have declined over the years which is one of the things that was a plus with employment at the Boeing Company. If you want to retain good folks you have to be willing to compensate them for the work performed and encourage them to go above and beyond just doing the minimum. 
As far as the management goes, they have removed most of the incentives for going into management and the changes have been evident in the attitudes of some of the managers. I have witnessed many managers that let the troops know that they are not happy with the lack of being properly compensated for overtime and lack of upper management support.

review_title: Decent if you know what to expect
pros: The company is very comfy to work at, and the pay and bennies are pretty decent. The workload is pretty manageable, and I didn't often feel pressured to work more than 40 hrs a week. Engineers still get overtime, which is amazing. There are a lot of people that work there that are passionate about aerospace with amazing stories. Two weeks off at Christmas is nice, even if I feel the less senior people at the company could use more vacation time. Just don't expect much of a pay raise unless you get extremely lucky and work on an important project.
cons: When I started, I really enjoyed it. Granted, I was younger and this was my first job at a large company. It quickly becomes obvious that most engineers are just interchangeable "work units" to management, intended to crank out product. Despite what they tell you, moving from position to position is not wise to do for career advancement because of their horrible skill code system. If you switch skill codes, you essentially reset any possibility of a promotion for at least 3-4 years. They fire and re-hire people on a regular cycle to keep costs down. If you are ok with the possibility boomeranging back and forth from employment to unemployment every 3 years or so, go for it. When they finally let me go during covid after 9 consecutive years of service and surviving several mass layoffs, I decided I didn't want to do that anymore and have since switched careers.

review_title: Great place to start your career and spend a few years
job_title: Structures and Payload Design Engineer in Everett, WA
pros:
Pay was good considering I joined them fresh out of college.

Benefits were great, 401k matching was generous (union), healthcare was low cost with generous company HSA contribution every year. 

Vacation wise, they could be better but considering you can accumulate vacation and sick leave (union), it was not bad.

Back when the company was doing good, bonuses were also a plus (EIP) although not as competitive as other tech companies in the Puget Sound area.

Had a pretty good experience with my immediate supervisors and colleagues.
cons:
Merit increases/pay raises were negotiated by the union. Before 2017, management had a 5% raise pool with a minimum of 1.5-2%  guaranteed raise every year. Assuming you were a high performer, you could expect anywhere from 4-7% raises every year. 

After the 2016 contract negotiation everything changed, the raise pool averaged 2-3% with 0% guaranteed raises. They incorporated a lump sum amount which averaged 2-3%. So under this scheme my 4-7% raise turned into a 2-3% raise and 2-3% lump sum (cash bonus). Not bad but not great considering Puget Sound is a high cost of living area with tech companies offering generous compensation packages

-Management and company cultured heavily entrenched in their ways and unwilling to change, partially due to government-related bureaucracy, but also just having a larger amount of older employees

If you want to stay on the production floor, it's easy enough to move around using the internal transfer tool, but salary is a different story.

-Management overly focused on numbers and metrics and thus push processes even if they're inefficient and cause more issues and work for the employees, "LEAN" manufacturing widely discussed but in reality is complete lip service in regards to real life situations on the floor.

review_title: Big Machine Stuck with Old Way of Thinking
job_title: Lead Manufacturing Engineer in Huntsville, AL
pros: As long as you are a performer, you have job security. Pretty much only way to be fired is to be laid off (which is a con for those that do perform and see non-performers making more money). Has great benefits package. Yearly bonus based on combination of personal and corporate divisions performance.
cons: Managers operate off of loyalty rather than objectiveness. Can't get a raise or promotion unless you leave the program. HR is a joke and are deterred from reporting despite their open/anonymous policy. If you are the only female in an entire department and can only 'anonymously' report from your company computer, is it really anonymous? Stories of people in the past say HR often doesn't provide support and end up only hurting your career. If they do support, then you still obtain a reputation among managers. Have heard hiring managers discuss candidates for a high ranking positions and actually said they would rather hire the women not because of her qualifications but because she seems 'easier to control'.

review_title: Best Aerospace  company I ever worked for
pros: I was exposed to many exciting  work and career opportunities at Boeing over the years. The people, though, are what make boeing such a great place to work. Best run company I ever worked for (have worked for 10 companies in aerospace, hi-tech, and manufacturing as an engineer). Very enjoyable work atmosphere. Had many group pot-lucks for the holidays. made many friends there. People always go out of their way to help you get your job done. Management very helpful to develop your career and provide other work opportunities to learn other job skills. Flexible work hours, great benefits, great people. Most interesting company culture I was ever exposed to.
cons: Can be very challenging  to get your work done on time. Must work hard/develop good time management skills.

review_title: Going More in the Wrong Direction
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Benefits are really good minus the salary but they more than make up in benefits.
They pay for schooling which honestly is the best in the industry.
Very little performance is required. There are large swaths of the company where zero work is required and managers are not capable letting go of people. If you are even half talented you are going to rise above the rest of the company. I would still recommend working there just educate yourself so they don't teach you how to do things incorrectly. That way you will still be marketable.
cons: The people in charge have very little understanding of software. They see software tools as a cost rather than something needed to do your job more efficiently. They don't really have a concept of efficiency as a metric. First time quality is lacking. The tools are at least 10 years behind throughout the company. Simple source control principles are not known by the majority contributors. The facilities are in disrepair. The restrooms are unclean and unmaintained to the point where I was embarrassed to bring in customers because it was unprofessional. They are basically taking any money to spend on folks and giving it to the management who are generally failing. They rotate them through after they lose programs instead of marching people out of the door for failure. This is demotivating for those who work hard and want to excel.

review_title: Met some great people but disappointed overall
pros: Health benefits are pretty good and their 401k match is the best I've ever seen. Adding Boeing to your resume is a nice to have especially if you're up and coming. You'll meet some of the nicest and collaborative people if you're lucky.
cons: Lots of tenured people are basically waiting to get their turn to get promoted to a higher level. Managers aren't necessarily looking to help advance your career as they should unless you're part of their clique. Morale has been even worse in 2021 compared to 2020 when all the layoffs were happening. Technology is also behind the times. It is super political especially in management. Managers call themselves leaders bc they think it's what they are by title but unfortunately, it is just a facade that most people can see right through. They're talking the talk but not walking the walk. Top talent aren't valued and as a result, many leave.

review_title: Not as advertised. BCFP is neither rigorous nor "accelerating"
job_title: Business Career Foundation Program in Seattle, WA
pros: Good benefits (health insurance, 401k)
cons:
1. Management does not actually care about early career employees. You can spend two years in the BCFP and then place out of the program into another entry level job
2. Salary is far below industry standards
3. Some pockets of extremely toxic work culture (i.e. backstabbing, coworkers who complain about those who take PTO because they have to backfill their work, micromanagement, distrust among teams, I could go on and on...)
4. The BCFP is a glorified early career program that promises participants an accelerated career track, but you will likely spend a year and a half doing administrative work (or doing no real work at all under the guise of "shadowing")
5. Program managers are either clueless or willfully ignorant of the program's shortcomings
